title: Introduction to msigdbr
text: Pathway analysis common task genomics research many available R-based software tools. Depending tool, may necessary import pathways, translate genes appropriate species, convert symbols IDs, format resulting object. msigdbr R package provides Molecular Signatures Database (MSigDB) gene sets typically used Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) software: R-friendly “tidy” format one gene pair per row multiple frequently studied model organisms, mouse, rat, pig, zebrafish, fly, yeast, addition original human genes gene symbols well NCBI Entrez Ensembl IDs without accessing external resources requiring active internet connection Please aware orthologs computationally predicted gene level. full pathways may well conserved across species.

title: Introduction to msigdbr
text: package can installed CRAN. package includes small subset full MSigDB database due CRAN size limitations. Please install msigdbdf package access full MSigDB database:

title: Introduction to msigdbr
text: Load package. gene sets database can retrieved specifying species interest. can retrieve data just specific collection, Hallmark gene sets. can specify sub-collection, C2 (curated) CGP (chemical genetic perturbations) gene sets. require precise filtering, msigdbr() function output data frame can manipulated using standard methods. example, can subset specific collection using dplyr. version MSigDB database stored db_version column returned data frame.
code: library(msigdbr) all_gene_sets <- msigdbr(species = "Mus musculus") head(all_gene_sets) #> # A tibble: 6 × 22 #>   gene_symbol ncbi_gene ensembl_gene      db_gene_sy…¹ db_ncbi_gene db_ensembl…² #>   <chr>           <int> <chr>             <chr>        <chr>        <chr>        #> 1 Abcc4          239273 ENSMUSG000000328… ABCC4        10257        ENSG0000012… #> 2 Abraxas2       109359 ENSMUSG000000309… ABRAXAS2     23172        ENSG0000016… #> 3 Actn4           60595 ENSMUSG000000548… ACTN4        81           ENSG0000013… #> 4 Acvr1           11477 ENSMUSG000000268… ACVR1        90           ENSG0000011… #> 5 Adam9           11502 ENSMUSG000000315… ADAM9        8754         ENSG0000016… #> 6 Adamts5         23794 ENSMUSG000000228… ADAMTS5      11096        ENSG0000015… #> # ℹ abbreviated names: ¹​db_gene_symbol, ²​db_ensembl_gene #> # ℹ 16 more variables: source_gene <chr>, gs_id <chr>, gs_name <chr>, #> #   gs_collection <chr>, gs_subcollection <chr>, gs_collection_name <chr>, #> #   gs_description <chr>, gs_source_species <chr>, gs_pmid <chr>, #> #   gs_geoid <chr>, gs_url <chr>, db_version <chr>, db_target_species <chr>, #> #   ortholog_taxon_id <int>, ortholog_sources <chr>, num_ortholog_sources <dbl> h_gene_sets <- msigdbr(species = "mouse", collection = "H") head(h_gene_sets) #> # A tibble: 6 × 22 #>   gene_symbol ncbi_gene ensembl_gene      db_gene_sy…¹ db_ncbi_gene db_ensembl…² #>   <chr>           <int> <chr>             <chr>        <chr>        <chr>        #> 1 Abca1           11303 ENSMUSG000000152… ABCA1        19           ENSG0000016… #> 2 Abcb8           74610 ENSMUSG000000289… ABCB8        11194        ENSG0000019… #> 3 Acaa2           52538 ENSMUSG000000368… ACAA2        10449        ENSG0000016… #> 4 Acadl           11363 ENSMUSG000000260… ACADL        33           ENSG0000011… #> 5 Acadm           11364 ENSMUSG000000629… ACADM        34           ENSG0000011… #> 6 Acads           11409 ENSMUSG000000295… ACADS        35           ENSG0000012… #> # ℹ abbreviated names: ¹​db_gene_symbol, ²​db_ensembl_gene #> # ℹ 16 more variables: source_gene <chr>, gs_id <chr>, gs_name <chr>, #> #   gs_collection <chr>, gs_subcollection <chr>, gs_collection_name <chr>, #> #   gs_description <chr>, gs_source_species <chr>, gs_pmid <chr>, #> #   gs_geoid <chr>, gs_url <chr>, db_version <chr>, db_target_species <chr>, #> #   ortholog_taxon_id <int>, ortholog_sources <chr>, num_ortholog_sources <dbl> cgp_gene_sets <- msigdbr(species = "mouse", collection = "C2", subcollection = "CGP") head(cgp_gene_sets) #> # A tibble: 6 × 22 #>   gene_symbol ncbi_gene ensembl_gene      db_gene_sy…¹ db_ncbi_gene db_ensembl…² #>   <chr>           <int> <chr>             <chr>        <chr>        <chr>        #> 1 Ahnak           66395 ENSMUSG000000698… AHNAK        79026        ENSG0000012… #> 2 Alcam           11658 ENSMUSG000000226… ALCAM        214          ENSG0000017… #> 3 Ankrd40         71452 ENSMUSG000000208… ANKRD40      91369        ENSG0000015… #> 4 Arid1a          93760 ENSMUSG000000078… ARID1A       8289         ENSG0000011… #> 5 Bckdhb          12040 ENSMUSG000000322… BCKDHB       594          ENSG0000008… #> 6 AU021092       239691 ENSMUSG000000516… C16orf89     146556       ENSG0000015… #> # ℹ abbreviated names: ¹​db_gene_symbol, ²​db_ensembl_gene #> # ℹ 16 more variables: source_gene <chr>, gs_id <chr>, gs_name <chr>, #> #   gs_collection <chr>, gs_subcollection <chr>, gs_collection_name <chr>, #> #   gs_description <chr>, gs_source_species <chr>, gs_pmid <chr>, #> #   gs_geoid <chr>, gs_url <chr>, db_version <chr>, db_target_species <chr>, #> #   ortholog_taxon_id <int>, ortholog_sources <chr>, num_ortholog_sources <dbl> all_gene_sets |>   dplyr::filter(gs_collection == "H") |>   head() #> # A tibble: 6 × 22 #>   gene_symbol ncbi_gene ensembl_gene      db_gene_sy…¹ db_ncbi_gene db_ensembl…² #>   <chr>           <int> <chr>             <chr>        <chr>        <chr>        #> 1 Abca1           11303 ENSMUSG000000152… ABCA1        19           ENSG0000016… #> 2 Abcb8           74610 ENSMUSG000000289… ABCB8        11194        ENSG0000019… #> 3 Acaa2           52538 ENSMUSG000000368… ACAA2        10449        ENSG0000016… #> 4 Acadl           11363 ENSMUSG000000260… ACADL        33           ENSG0000011… #> 5 Acadm           11364 ENSMUSG000000629… ACADM        34           ENSG0000011… #> 6 Acads           11409 ENSMUSG000000295… ACADS        35           ENSG0000012… #> #   gs_description <chr>, gs_source_species <chr>, gs_pmid <chr>, #> #   gs_geoid <chr>, gs_url <chr>, db_version <chr>, db_target_species <chr>, #> #   ortholog_taxon_id <int>, ortholog_sources <chr>, num_ortholog_sources <dbl> unique(all_gene_sets$db_version) #> [1] "2024.1.Hs"

title: Introduction to msigdbr
text: helper functions assist setting msigdbr() parameters. Use msigdbr_species() check available species. scientific common names acceptable msigdbr() function. Use msigdbr_collections() check available collections.
code: msigdbr_species() #> # A tibble: 20 × 2 #>    species_name                    species_common_name                           #>    <chr>                           <chr> Caenorhabditis elegans          NA                                            #>  4 Canis lupus familiaris          dog, dogs                                     #>  5 Danio rerio                     leopard danio, zebra danio, zebra fish, zebr… #>  6 Drosophila melanogaster         fruit fly                                     #>  7 Equus caballus                  domestic horse, equine, horse short-tailed opossum                     #> 13 Mus musculus                    house mouse, mouse                            #> 14 Ornithorhynchus anatinus        duck-billed platypus, duckbill platypus, pla… #> 15 Pan troglodytes                 chimpanzee                                    #> 16 Rattus norvegicus               brown rat, Norway rat, rat, rats              #> 17 Saccharomyces cerevisiae        baker's yeast, brewer's yeast, S. cerevisiae  #> 18 Schizosaccharomyces pombe 972h- NA                                            #> 19 Sus scrofa                      pig, pigs, swine, wild boar                   #> 20 Xenopus tropicalis              tropical clawed frog, western clawed frog msigdbr_collections() #> # A tibble: 25 × 4 #>    gs_collection gs_subcollection  gs_collection_name               num_genesets #>    <chr>         <chr>             <chr>                                   <int> #>  1 C1            ""                "Positional" Neighborhoods"               427 #> 16 C4            "CM"              "Cancer Modules"                          431 #> 17 C5            "GO:BP"           "GO Biological Process"                  7608 title: Introduction to msigdbr
text: msigdbr output can used various pathway analysis packages. Use gene sets data frame clusterProfiler genes NCBI/Entrez IDs. Use gene sets data frame clusterProfiler genes gene symbols. Use gene sets data frame fgsea. Use gene sets data frame GSVA.
code: msigdbr_t2g <- dplyr::distinct(msigdbr_df, gs_name, ncbi_gene) enricher(gene = gene_ids_vector, TERM2GENE = msigdbr_t2g, ...) msigdbr_t2g <- dplyr::distinct(msigdbr_df, gs_name, gene_symbol) enricher(gene = gene_symbols_vector, TERM2GENE = msigdbr_t2g, ...) msigdbr_list <- split(x = msigdbr_df$gene_symbol, f = msigdbr_df$gs_name) fgsea(pathways = msigdbr_list, ...) msigdbr_list <- split(x = msigdbr_df$gene_symbol, f = msigdbr_df$gs_name) gsva(gset.idx.list = msigdbr_list, ...)

title: Introduction to msigdbr
text: version MSigDB used? MSigDB version stored db_version column returned data frame. can check version used unique(msigdbr_df$db_version). use package can download gene sets directly MSigDB? package makes convenient work MSigDB gene sets R. don’t need download GMT files import . don’t need learn restructure output make compatible downstream tools. don’t need convert genes organism working non-human data. Can convert human mouse genes just adjusting gene capitalization? work , , genes. Can convert human genes organism instead using package? One popular method using biomaRt package. may still end dozens homologs genes, additional cleanup may helpful. Aren’t already similar tools? resources provide msigdbr functionality served inspiration package. WEHI provides MSigDB gene sets R format human mouse. MSigDF recent ToledoEM/msigdf fork provide tidyverse-friendly data frame. updated varying frequencies may based latest version MSigDB. Since 2022, GSEA/MSigDB team provides collections natively mouse don’t require orthology conversion. questions? can submit feedback report bugs GitHub.

title: Introduction to msigdbr
text: Molecular Signatures Database (MSigDB) collection gene sets originally created use Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) software. cite use underlying MSigDB data, reference Subramanian, Tamayo, et al. (2005, PNAS) one following appropriate: Liberzon, et al. (2011, Bioinformatics), Liberzon, et al. (2015, Cell Systems), Castanza, et al. (2023, Nature Methods) also source gene set. Gene homologs provided HUGO Gene Nomenclature Committee European Bioinformatics Institute integrates orthology assertions predicted human genes eggNOG, Ensembl Compara, HGNC, HomoloGene, Inparanoid, NCBI Gene Orthology, OMA, OrthoDB, OrthoMCL, Panther, PhylomeDB, TreeFam ZFIN. human equivalent within species, ortholog supported largest number databases used. information cite msigdbr R package, run citation("msigdbr").

title: Authors and Citation
text: Dolgalev (2025). msigdbr: MSigDB Gene Sets Multiple Organisms Tidy Data Format. R package version 10.0.1.9000, https://igordot.github.io/msigdbr/.

title: MSigDB gene sets R package
text: msigdbr R package provides Molecular Signatures Database (MSigDB) gene sets typically used Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) software: R-friendly “tidy” format one gene pair per row multiple frequently studied model organisms, mouse, rat, pig, zebrafish, fly, yeast, addition original human genes gene symbols well NCBI Entrez Ensembl IDs without accessing external resources requiring active internet connection

title: MSigDB gene sets R package
text: package can installed CRAN.

title: MSigDB gene sets R package
text: package data can accessed using msigdbr() function, returns data frame gene sets member genes. example, can retrieve mouse genes C2 (curated) CGP (chemical genetic perturbations) gene sets. Check documentation website information.

what: msigdbr: MSigDB Gene Sets for Multiple Organisms in a Tidy Data Format — msigdbr-package
title: msigdbr: MSigDB Gene Sets for Multiple Organisms in a Tidy Data Format — msigdbr-package
text: Provides 'Molecular Signatures Database' (MSigDB) gene sets typically used 'Gene Set Enrichment Analysis' (GSEA) software (Subramanian et al. 2005 doi:10.1073/pnas.0506580102 , Liberzon et al. 2015 doi:10.1016/j.cels.2015.12.004 , Castanza et al. 2023 doi:10.1038/s41592-023-02014-7 ) R data frame. package includes human genes listed MSigDB well corresponding symbols IDs frequently studied model organisms mouse, rat, pig, fly, yeast.

title: msigdbr: MSigDB Gene Sets for Multiple Organisms in a Tidy Data Format — msigdbr-package
text: Maintainer: Igor Dolgalev igor.dolgalev@nyumc.org (ORCID)

what: Retrieve the gene sets data frame — msigdbr
title: Retrieve the gene sets data frame — msigdbr
text: Retrieve data frame gene sets member genes. original human genes can converted corresponding counterparts various model organisms, including mouse, rat, pig, zebrafish, fly, yeast. output includes gene symbols along NCBI Ensembl IDs.

title: Retrieve the gene sets data frame — msigdbr
code: msigdbr(   species = "Homo sapiens",   db_species = "HS",   collection = NULL,   subcollection = NULL,   category = deprecated(),   subcategory = deprecated() )

title: Retrieve the gene sets data frame — msigdbr
text: species Species name output genes, "Homo sapiens" "Mus musculus". Use msigdbr_species() available options. db_species Species abbreviation human mouse databases ("HS" "MM"). collection Collection abbreviation, "H" "C1". Use msigdbr_collections() available options. subcollection Sub-collection abbreviation, "CGP" "BP". Use msigdbr_collections() available options. category use collection argument subcategory use subcollection argument

title: Retrieve the gene sets data frame — msigdbr
text: data frame gene sets one gene per row.

title: Retrieve the gene sets data frame — msigdbr
text: Historically, MSigDB resource tailored analysis human-specific datasets, gene sets exclusively aligned human genome. Starting release 2022.1, MSigDB incorporated database mouse-native gene sets split human mouse divisions ("Hs" "Mm"). one provided approved gene symbols respective species. versioning convention MSigDB format Year.Release.Species. genes within gene set may originate species different database target species indicated gs_source_species db_target_species fields. Mouse MSigDB includes gene sets curated mouse-centric datasets specified native mouse gene identifiers, eliminating need ortholog mapping. access full dataset, please install msigdbdf package (available CRAN):

title: Retrieve the gene sets data frame — msigdbr
text: https://www.gsea-msigdb.org/gsea/msigdb/index.jsp

title: msigdbr 10.0.1
text: CRAN release: 2025-03-19 Updated documentation.

title: msigdbr 10.0.0
text: CRAN release: 2025-03-12 Removed MSigDB data (now separate package msigdbdf). Updated package versioning scheme tied MSigDB release. Added support mouse versions MSigDB (msigdbr() gains db_species argument). Updated annotation fields returned gene sets. Updated msigdbr() arguments gs_cat gs_subcat gs_collection gs_subcollection.

title: msigdbr 2023.1.1
text: Based MSigDB v2023.1.Hs release. available CRAN.

title: msigdbr 2022.1.1
text: Based MSigDB v2022.1.Hs release. available CRAN.

title: msigdbr 7.5.1
text: CRAN release: 2022-03-30 Based MSigDB v7.5.1 release.

title: msigdbr 7.4.1
text: CRAN release: 2021-05-05 Based MSigDB v7.4 release. Added Ensembl gene IDs returned gene sets.

title: msigdbr 7.2.1
text: CRAN release: 2020-10-02 Based MSigDB v7.2 release. Added annotation fields returned gene sets. Added msigdbr_species() alternative msigdbr_show_species(). Added msigdbr_collections().

title: msigdbr 7.1.1
text: CRAN release: 2020-05-14 Based MSigDB v7.1 release. Increased ortholog prediction stringency.

title: msigdbr 7.0.1
text: CRAN release: 2019-09-04 Based MSigDB v7.0 release. Fixed output selecting multiple collections.

title: msigdbr 6.2.1
text: CRAN release: 2018-10-09 Based MSigDB v6.2 release.

title: msigdbr 6.1.1
text: CRAN release: 2018-04-12 Based MSigDB v6.1 release. Initial CRAN submission.
